archetypes.name: Limits to Growth (Limits to Success)
archetypes.rationale: The model shows a reinforcing loop where Project Reputation drives Joining Rate, which increases Core Developers and improves PR Feedback, further enhancing reputation. However, this growth is limited by balancing loops: Core Developer turnover and capacity constraints create PR Review Delay, which negatively affects PR Feedback and Community Health, ultimately constraining further growth. This matches the classic Limits to Growth archetype where accelerating growth encounters limiting factors.

variables.name: Growth Pressure
variables.description: The pressure to maintain growth momentum as reputation and user base increase
variables.rationale: Needed to represent the driving force that exacerbates the limiting factors

variables.name: Capacity Constraint
variables.description: The maximum sustainable workload that core developers can handle effectively
variables.rationale: Needed to explicitly represent the limiting factor that creates the balancing loop

connections.rationale: Higher reputation creates more pressure to maintain growth and performance
Growth pressure increases workload on core developers, worsening review delays
More core developers increase the team's capacity to handle workload
Higher capacity reduces review delays, completing the balancing loop

archetypes.name: Shifting the Burden
archetypes.rationale: The model shows potential for shifting burden from long-term capacity building to short-term fixes. Core developers may focus on immediate PR reviews (short-term solution) rather than mentoring and knowledge transfer (fundamental solution). This is evidenced by the tension between PR Review Delay driving immediate action versus Implicit Knowledge Transfer building long-term capacity. The archetype fits because short-term fixes can undermine long-term capability development.

variables.name: Short Term Fix Pressure
variables.description: Pressure to address immediate problems like PR backlog rather than long-term capacity building
variables.rationale: Needed to represent the driving force for shifting to symptomatic solutions

variables.name: Long Term Capacity Building
variables.description: Investment in mentoring, documentation, and knowledge transfer activities
variables.rationale: Needed to explicitly represent the fundamental solution that gets neglected

connections.rationale: Long review delays create pressure for immediate action
Pressure for short-term fixes reduces investment in long-term capacity building
Capacity building increases the number of effective core developers over time
Capacity building activities enhance knowledge transfer effectiveness

archetypes.name: Tragedy of the Commons
archetypes.rationale: The model shows multiple user groups (New Contributors, Experienced Contributors, Core Developers) all drawing on the shared resource of Core Developer time for PR reviews and mentoring. As more contributors join and create pull requests, they collectively overload the limited Core Developer capacity, leading to PR Review Delay that negatively affects everyone. This matches the Tragedy of the Commons pattern where individual benefits conflict with collective resource depletion.

variables.name: Shared Resource Depletion
variables.description: The degree to which core developer time and attention is being overutilized
variables.rationale: Needed to represent the depletion of the shared resource that affects all participants

variables.name: Individual Benefit Perception
variables.description: Perceived benefit to individual contributors from submitting more PRs or issues
variables.rationale: Needed to represent the driving force for individual actions that deplete shared resources

connections.rationale: More contributors increase demand on the shared core developer resource
Experienced contributors also consume core developer time for complex reviews
More pull requests increase the workload on the shared resource
Resource depletion directly causes longer review delays for everyone
Higher reputation increases perceived benefits of participation
Higher perceived benefits drive more individual contribution activity
